66535.title: evening dress
66535.description:
The silk chiffon garment is shaped in the form of a kaftan with two large arm lengths which are hidden in the dress silhouette and are not completely visible until the garment is on a form. The entire garment is composed of the two-layer front and back lengths of silk chiffon which are seamed together at the proper left and right sides above and below open rhinestone-lined armholes. The dress is composed of two separate layers of silk chiffon that have a range of blue-ish gray color. The range of colors begins with the lightest blue on the proper right side and extends to a dark bluish-gray on the proper left side when viewed from the front. The added rhinestones are sewn to both layers of the silk chiffon making some more vibrant than others depending on which layer these rhinestones are attached to. 

When viewed from the front, the rhinestones that are part of the "body" of the garment are attached to the bottom layer but are still quite visible. These rhinestones are laid out in a pattern that extends from the neck of the garment with increasing space between rhinestones the further away they are from the neckline. In addition to the "body" of the textile, rhinestones outline the armholes and neckline of the garment. These rhinestones are placed closely together and form a triple linear outline of these areas of the garment. They are part of the exterior layer of silk chiffon and are more vibrant than the previously described rhinestones. This same pattern of rhinestone placement can be seen from the back as well. The side seams of the silk chiffon are (machined?) stitched with light blue thread in a                        pattern. The bottom hem is turned up and (hand?) stitched in a pattern. Different shades of blue thread were used to correspond to the different shades of silk chiffon. The hem line is uneven across the bottom of the dress and this is visible when seen in close proximity.
66535.provenance:
(Leslie Hindman Auctioneers, Chicago, Illinois); {1} purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2009.

{1} See catalogue, Leslie Hindman Auctioneers, Vintage Couture and Accessories, 21 September 2008, lot 124.

extended_text.content:
Halston created beautiful kaftans that were both comfortable and flattering to a variety of body types. This piece exemplifies Halston’s aesthetic by exhibiting his commitment to the use of fine fabrics, expertly devised layering, and distinctive surface treatment.

This kaftan evening dress is composed of two layers of silk chiffon dyed in a gradated blueish gray to dark blue. The piece sparkles as the wearer moves, owing to the strategically placed rhinestones attached to the different layers.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

66535.exhibit_history:
An American Legacy; Norell, Blass, Halston & Sprouse
Paul Textile and Fashion Arts galleries, IMA
May 4, 2012 - January 27, 2013

18750.title: quilt
18750.creation_notes:
Made for Calvin Hicks, whose name is in central medallion of the quilt.

DATE CREATED= Per Niloo Paydar, Textile and Fashion Arts Curator, and Rebecca McNamara, Curatorial Coordinator: because we cannot be 100% certain about the maker, the date should remain vague; however, if the maker is correct, the quilt was most likely made between 1865, when Virginia Lacy married Calvin Hicks, and 1895, by when Virginia had died and Calvin married Sallie.

PLACE OF CREATION= Indiana OR Texas; most likely Texas based on possible attribution. See notes in historical file.
18750.provenance:
Calvin Hicks. Marie Webster, Indiana.{1} Mrs. Gerrish Thurber, Indianapolis; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1979. 

{1} Marie Webster purchased this quilt at auction for $3. It was sold by the second wife of former owner Calvin Hicks. Francis C. Miller, "Marion is Home of World Authority on Quilting Art," The Marion Daily Chronicle, May 28, 1925, 8.
18750.inscription:
Embroidered, center: Calvin / HICKS
Inscribed, back, lower left corner (when viewed from front): Marie Webster

67463.title: Push AA <----> AB / 200 (c)
67463.credit_line: Purchased with funds provided by Mark Demerly, Mark and Jean Easter, Kent Hawryluk, Susie Jacobs, Pat and James LaCrosse Ron Reeve, Anna and James White, Trent Spence, George and Jan Rubin, and Mary Wicker

extended_text.content:
Type A is the collaboration of Adam Ames (b. 1969) and Andrew Bordwin (b. 1964), who have worked together since 1998. Employing a variety of media, Type A creates artworks that address issues of masculinity, competition and collaboration in contemporary society.

Part of their Push series, which includes video, drawings and photographs, this large-scale drawing is a document of a performance conducted in their studio, where the two artists operated as opposing forces in an act that blended both competition and collaboration. To create the drawing, Bordwin and Ames took turns standing, then pushing each other across the surface of a large piece of paper. They then outlined the steps that each had taken, and the areas in which they fell, numbering them systematically to diagram a sequence of movement. While charting through their bodies a distillation of a competitive drive, they simultaneously created a work that represents a constructive creative partnership.

The artists described the project: "The result is part dance chart, part Twister, part motion study. The paper becomes a wrestling ring or battleground, the evidence of each push documented with footprints and smudges. The drawings exist as detailed evidence, a brief history of itself that can be used to reconstruct the entire process after the fact by carefully examining and sequencing each footprint. Each drawing is made by choice and by chance. Pushes are made with intention, whether to accentuate an emerging structure in the drawing, create a specific effect, or avoid certain resolved areas. The element of chance is always present, and the drawing emerges as much by chaos as by order. Composure and control are lost, then regained, and the resolution recorded."
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

11921.title: Solarized Red with Blue and Yellow
11921.description: Masters of Contemporary Glass (IMA, 1997), cat. 51, described the medium/support as: Glass, fused, hand-shaped, ground and polished. The variation now in the Medium and Support field ("thermo-formed glass, cut and polished") matches that used on the wall label for the 2013 gallery installation, which was reviewed by Corning curator and modern/contemporary glass specialist Tina Oldknow.
11921.credit_line: Gift of Marilyn and Eugene Glick

14845.title: vase
14845.creation_notes: An example of this same form/design can be found in a Sept. 1916 issue of "The American Magazine of Art." Marblehead produced this same form/design multiple times, so it cannot be known at this time if the IMA's example is the one in the photograph; either way, the photograph implies the approximate design date, if not the manufacture date of the IMA's example. See historical file for more information.
14845.inscription: Impressed with monogram, underside: M [squared rigged ship] P

extended_text.content:
Marblehead was an American pottery named for a Massachusetts coastal town.

Originally conceived as part of a craft therapy program, this pottery is associated with the American Arts and Crafts movement.

This vase, which features a design of Viking ships, is rare because it has five colors.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

1176.title: coffee pot (part of Medallion tea and coffee service)
1176.inscription:
Inscribed on base, at underside: J.E. CALDWELL & CO.
Mark: lion passant facing left, anchor, gothic letter "G"
Inscribed: RV Gorham & Co. 211 1

extended_text.content:
This classical-revival style service is ornamented with rolled borders, cast medallions and duplicate etched leaf designs.

The design suggests a precision that was achieved through mass production, a trend that developed during this period.

Mark: lion passant facing left, anchor, gothic letter "G"
Inscribed: RV Gorham & Co. 211 8

extended_text.content:
This classical-revival style service is ornamented with rolled borders, cast medallions and duplicate etched leaf designs.

The design suggests a precision that was achieved through mass production, a trend that developed during this period.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

11361.title: evening dress with boa
11361.description: silk voided velvet dress with abstract pring in purple, orange, blue and white accompanied with boa of millinery flowers
11361.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Gerald L. Herzfeld
11361.provenance: Mrs. Gerald L. (Geraldine) Herzfeld,  (d. 2009) New York; through (Stan Weaver, New York); given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (June 20, 1985)
11361.dimensions:
A) dress: length 59 in.
B) boa: length 166 in.

extended_text.content:
Designs inspired by the psychedelic—a term frequently applied to brightly patterned or colored objects—were at the height of fashion during the 1967 Summer of Love. For this opulent evening gown, Blass combines the colors and patterning prominent in the then-emerging hippie culture with the style of classic Hollywood glamour, evident in the accompanying boa.

Blass’s use of luxurious fabrics resulted in garments that were both sophisticated and glamorous. This floor-length dress with fitted sleeves is constructed of printed silk satin with voided velvet in an abstract allover pattern. The boa, which is nearly fourteen feet long, was likely hand-assembled with individually dyed millinery petals.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

11361.exhibit_history:
An American Legacy; Norell, Blass, Halston & Sprouse
Paul Textile and Fashion Arts Galleries, IMA
May 4, 2012 - January 27, 2013
